label: Col. Edward Manigault Letter, October 5, 1861
description: This letter from Colonel Edward Manigault (1817-1874) to South Carolina Governor Francis Wilkinson Pickens (1805-1869) was written in Charleston, South Carolina, on October 5, 1861. Col. Edward Manigault was the Chief of Ordnance for South Carolina in 1861. The letter is in reference to the transferring of funds to cover the cost of the "establishment of a Coast Police for the State of South Carolina." Page 3 is a handwritten enclosed form dated October 7, 1861, for the Gov. to sign and send with a draft to Gen. DeSaussure.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Ordnance Office
Charleston, Oct. 5, 1861
His Excellency
Gov. F. W. Pickens
Columbia, S. C.

Sir
Genl. W. G. DeSaussure, Secretary of Treasury Executive Department, has requested me to sign an Order which he brought to me, countersigned by yourself, to the Treasurer of the Lower Division, to deliver to Thomas R. Waring, Esq. Cashier Bank of State of So. Ca., the One Thousand five hundred certificates required to be issued by him under an Act entitled "An Act for the establishment of a Coast Police for the State of South Carolina." - The object of Genl DeSaussure being to deposit said Certificates, as Collateral Security, in the Bank of the State, upon which an advance might be made by the Bank. -
The Act referred to makes the Sum of One hundred and Fifty thousand Dollars in the Treasury of the State subject to the Draft of the Ordnance Officer, countersigned by the Governor, the same to be employed for the purposes specified. But it does not, so far as I can perceive, give to the parties named, the control of the Certificates themselves; which are simply the means or instruments, by which the amount is to be raised. - I therefore respectfully suggest that, if Your Excellency needs the amount, you will send me the Draft for the amount
[page 2]
of One Hundred and fifty thousand Dollars appropriated under the act referred to; which I will sign at Your request; and then the Secretary of the Treasury, the Treasurer of the Lower Division, and the Bank of the State, may take such measures as they may deem proper to realize the amount (the same not being at present in the Treasury)
By the terms of the Act, the Draft of the Ordnance Officer is necessary to procure the money, but he is neither charged with the disbursement of the same, nor the accounting for it; the Governor having full charge of the said fund. - Upon Your Excellency's notifying me to that effect I will therefore readily give the Draft you require. - But it is the opinion of the Attorney General, whom I have consulted as to the extent of my responsibility in the matter, that such a notification from Your Excellency should be given me in writing. - Accordingly, I have the honor to request that Your Excellency will sign the enclosed form, and send the same, together with a Draft for One Hundred and Fifty Thousand Dollars, countersigned by yourself, to Genl. DeSaussure. - Upon his handing the same to me I will immediately sign the Draft and return it to him, to be disposed of as Your Excellency deems proper. 
Very Respectfully
Your Obed. Sevt.
Edward Manigault
Col. Ordnance. -
[page 3, said enclosed form]
Columbia
7. Oct. 1861
To Col. Ed. Manigault - Ordnance officer
Sir
I enclose a Draft for One Hundred and Fifty Thousand Dollars ($150,000) on the Treasurer of the Lower Division, countersigned by myself, which the Ordnance Officer will please sign; as the Amount is needed for the purposes specified and provided for, under the 1st and 2nd Sections of an Act entitled "An Act for the establishment of a Coast Police for the State of South Carolina." - 
After signature the Draft will be returned to Genl. W. G. DeSaussure, Secretary of Treasury Executive Department. - 
[in light pencil]
(Signed) F. W. Pickens
[page 4, back of page 1]
Col. Manigault
Ordnance officer
with a draft -
for $150,000 - and
the reason why it 
is to be signed
7. Oct. 1861
